Chapter 8 explains instinct. Instincts are actions beneficial to survival performed by all members of a species in the same way without their knowing for what purpose they are performed.

I believe that instincts are passed on to

an organism's offspring in the same way physical characteristics are transmitted.

It would be beneficial to the survival of

a species if instincts could change in response to environmental changes.

Instincts are formed for the benefit

of a particular species and never

for the benefit of another species.

A look at cuckoo birds, ants,

and honey bees allows us to understand

how instincts are selected, change, and preserved.

We cuckoo birds

have an instinct that make us place our

eggs in the nests

of other birds.

Because our children do all the work for us we adults can play and eat.

We know how

to build our houses efficiently by not wasting any of our valuable wax.
